page.title: 02A BRIEF HISTORY-QUEEN CAMEL
page.content: Originally there were two villages East and West Camel. Edward 1 gave East Camel to his wife. The village continued to be owned by the Queens of England and became known as Queen's Camel. Elizabeth 1 exchanged ownership with the Mildmay family. In 1639 a fire thought to have been started by aggrieved gypsies burnt down 70 houses in Queen Camel. They were rebuilt, using local stone from Camel Hill. There were 2 mills in each village. The one at the East end of Queen Camel and the one in the area in front of the church at West Camel were both recorded in the Domesday book. During the civil war, Cromwell's troops camped on Camel Hill, coming down into Queen Camel to damage the church. In the last 900 years the population has risen from 200 to 700.
